bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, May 12, 1929

div1.p: Carter reports that she and Frost made determinations about the use of maps and the establishment of an alphabetical list of geographic references for the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, May 12, 1929
div1.opener:

Book. Misel /
Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
May 12, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I had a very satisfactory talk with Dr. Frost in Bal-
timore last week (so far as the outline maps were concerned; as well
as concerning some other details of his plans for the work on which my own, and
Miss Brown's activities would be dependent).

Re the outline maps, I took them over with me, rather an un-
dertaking as they are almost as large as I am and will neither fold nor
roll. Dr. Frost was very much pleased with them. They are beautifully
done. Dr. Frost decided to only use one map for Middle America, the
out-lying islands and the northern part of South America. I had had two
made in accordance with Dr. Morley's and my tentative plans of 1926.
However, the duplicate will be excellent for experimental lettering,
which is needed on account of both the ancient and modern names of
many places having to be given. This, as Dr. Frost says, will have to
be most carefully done in order not to interfere with the appearance of
the maps--i. e. must be “tried out.” I shall probably have to have a
photostat made of the map of Mercator's projection of the West Coast
of Africa and the East Coast of America with inter-lying islands. This,
unless I find it is cheaper to have a duplicate outline drawn., for the
aforesaid trying out.

Dr. Frost also approved my suggestion that Miss Brown and
I go through Father's MS, and make an alphabetic list (card index) of
the places (towns, rivers, islands etc. etc.) mentioned by Father which
would be needed for filling in the maps. This list has, of course,
already been started, indeed, I wrote to Miss Brown before leaving Bal-
timore so that she could begin work before my return.

Dr. Frost hopes to soon be able to resume work on the
on the
-2-
final editing of the the MS. Were it not for many unexpected things coming
up he could have done so e'er this. For instance, he had to go to
Philadelphia last week as an expert witness. The case was postponed, aftterer
his arrival, but not before he had lost valuable time both by his
actual absence, his preparations therefor etc. etc. However, I am hop-
ing soon to be called over to Baltimore again and, in the interim, can have the satis-
faction of getting the maps “under way.” I asked Dr. Ramsey if, before
the outline map for Africa (West) were filled in, he would go over my
list, which he said he would be glad to do. I am sure this will be a
real help.

I had the privelege and happiness of a most interesting talk
with Dr. Welch at a dinner in Baltimore. As you know, he is much in-
terested in Father's book and says that he has frequently mentioned it
abroad, where its publication is also being looked forward to.
With very best remembrances, I remain
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
